Meet The Men Behind Movember

19/11/2019

Alice Weetman explores the iconic campaign and speaks to some of the men growing the â€˜moâ€™ in York in aid of charity

Image by RpL2144

By Alice Weetman

The Movember movement started in 2003 when two friends, Travis Garone and Luke Slattery, sat down for a quiet beer in the Australian town of Fitzroy and joked about bringing the tash back. After talking to other friends about their plan, and inspired by another friendâ€™s mother raising money for breast cancer, they pulled together to create the Movember Campaign, which has now raised more than Â£440 million for research into menâ€™s health and wellbeing, and funded 1,250 menâ€™s health projects since 2003. Movemberâ€™s mission is not an easy one. They aim to reduce the number of men dying prematurely by 25 per cent by the year 2030, and although originally concentrated on prostate cancer, their focus has widened to testicular cancer, mental health and male suicide prevention.

Despite starting so far away, Movember has now spread to the University of York and in particular our sports teams. The Movember movement in York doesnâ€™t just include the mos being grown but has brought with it events such as Movember Karaoke, that shook the Glasshouse on the 15th, and the Breakz & Chameleon DJ set that will be taking place in The Lounge on 22 November. The Universityâ€™s collective Movember Target of Â£15,000 is well on its way to already being beaten, with just over Â£13,900 raised with still two weeks of the month left. 20 sports teams and societies, including York Mountaineering Club, UYRUFC, UYVC and numerous college football teams are all taking part. A total of 265 men on campus, all growing moustaches in the name of menâ€™s wellbeing.

Cancer was the original focus point of Movember. Testicular cancer is the most common cancer in men aged 15-29, with one in 20 diagnosed with the disease losing their lives. In the UK, one in eight men will be diagnosed with prostate cancer in their lifetime, making it the second most common cancer in men, with 1.4 million diagnosed globally every year. With the money raised through Movember, the aim is to push medical research to slow and stop tumour progression, improve clinic quality, and strive to educate men on warning signs and symptoms for both illnesses. By equipping men with the knowledge and confidence to make the right choices for their health, prevention is made easier and a higher quality of life can be achieved.

In more recent years, mental health issues have become a huge talking point in the media and society as a whole, due to their ever increasing impact, and the lack of resources that are being provided to cope with this mental health crisis. Movember wants to get men talking to each other about their mental health, throwing away the stigmas attached to issues such as depression and anxiety. Globally, three out of four suicides are male. 75 per cent of suicides in the UK are male. Every minute, a man takes his own life. This isnâ€™t right. This alone is clear evidence that not enough is being done to open up conversations around male mental health, and that there is something missing in the way of readily available support systems and prevention plans.  And this is where the Movember movement steps in. According to their 2018 Annual Report, Movember aims to put a stop to men dying early by â€œgiving men the facts about their health, and using the power of mass-media to drive behaviour change for men.â€ With greater awareness, and a reduction in the stigma associated with menâ€™s health, this may be possible. The money raised by the campaign is also poured into biomedical research, â€œcreating new, better and accessible health services or men, by bringing together the brightest minds from around the world to collaborate on research and innovative menâ€™s health projects, while sharing their findings and accelerating results.â€

The biggest part of Movember is, however, creating conversations around these topics, and bringing awareness to the forefront: â€œlistening to and learning from our community, and using what we know to advocate for all men.â€ With that being said we thought the best way to cover Movember was to talk to the men behind the moustaches. I spoke to some of the men behind the moustaches on campus. Although their moustaches might not be that impressive yet (pictures taken 14 November) what theyâ€™re doing for menâ€™s health and the conversation around it certainly is.

If you'd like to donate to the University's Movember page you can do so at the following link :https://uk.movember.com/mospace/network/YorkMovember
The Interviews:

Mehti Kendrick:
How have campaigns such as Movember change your views around menâ€™s health?
The Movember cause means a lot to me, men are three times more likely to die through suicide than women and the rate of deaths among under 25s has increased by 23.7% in the past year. This puts uni men (including myself) into a very dangerous bracket of increased suicide likelihood. That is why I feel as though it is a very important cause to get involved with as I can help shed light to those around me that they are not alone and myself, and everyone else involved in the cause, are accessible to talk to and available for support.
What do you hope will come from â€˜Movemberâ€™ in the future?
I hope that the Movember foundation will have lasting impacts throughout the year and help break down the stigma surrounding menâ€™s health. Of course, I think that there could always be a lot more campaigns on a lot more topics however I feel that Movember, as a one off entire month, has maintained its size and attention through being the only one of its kind. That being said, I would love to see more single events put on, either during the month or any of time of the year, similar to the Race for Life.
Why do you think men health, both mental and physical, are seen as slightly â€˜tabooâ€™ topics?
I think that often among uni sports â€˜ladsâ€™, people are often in a position where they want to show their peers that they are â€˜invincibleâ€™. Unfortunately that means not many boys are willing to open up with others as they assume nobody else is suffering alongside them. I feel that this bravado, often put on, can make topics such as the trials and tribulations of being a young man very taboo.
***Do you think campaigns like Movember have made a difference in how we look at topics such as male mental health? ***
One hundred percent. I feel that campaigns such as these are making a huge difference to not only how we look at the topics of male mental health, but also how we view our friendâ€™s feelings, and through this mutual recognition of peopleâ€™s understanding, do topics really become comfortable and normal to talk about.
How do you think we can continue the conversations around menâ€™s wellbeing after November?
I think the most important thing, once November is up, is to keep communication about serious topics going with your friends. Itâ€™s very easy to check on someone once in November and then assume that theyâ€™re fine or that now they know they can talk to you they will, when the reality of it is that communication needs to remain a steady flow on such topics. I think the media is great during Movember, and I do also think that there is still a lot of articles being made about menâ€™s health throughout the rest of the year, however with a topic like menâ€™s wellbeing, I think there could always be more done by the media.
Any top tips on maintaining the tash this month?
Yea, shoot for the moon, kings! No tash is too fancy!
